text: Jerome Powell made an interesting misstatement. Part of the Fed’s mandate says something like “stable prices.” But Powell called 2% inflation a part of the mandate: “I don’t feel we have con­vinc­ingly achieved our 2% man­date in a sym­met­ri­cal way”

text: I was very much influenced by Michigan labor economists. I also count myself as a labor theorist. But I have never taught labor economics and am not qualified to.

text: My main point about monopsony is that a minimum wage policy that was based on actual evidence about monopsony would be a very different policy than the one we have. In particular, it wouldn't be a one-size-fits all minimum wage, but one that varied by MPL & wedge.

text: “of­fi­cials con­tinue to re­vise lower their think­ing about the point at which the un­em­ploy­ment rate is con­sistent with sta­ble prices.. 4% to 4.6%, with the me­dian fall­ing to 4.3%. ..down from a me­dian..of 4.5% one year ago and 4.8% in 2016.” https://www.wsj.com/articles/fed-keeps-rates-unchanged-signals-no-more-increases-likely-this-year-11553104999 …

text: I just received an email from Jim Poterba to everyone in the NBER saying Alan Krueger is dead. This is a shock. He was a PhD classmate whom I talked to a lot while in the PhD program. My research on efficiency wages was a direct result of his championing of that research area
author: mileskimball

text: Also, they are acting as if money in the hands of the government does nothing for aggregate demand. That is wrong. Government spending is endogenous to interest rates, mainly because the official deficit numbers for most countries include interest expense.
author: mileskimball

text: They need to realize the principle of countervailing wealth effects and to think about all the many borrower-lender relationships in the economy. Only some of these involve the government on one side or the other.

text: I am convinced by the idea that the political power of public sector unions means that they are often effectively sitting on both sides of the bargaining table. That doesn't yield appropriate results.

text:
The Supreme Court did a bit of that in relation to public sector unions. 

My view of unions is that at this point in history, US private sector unions are pretty benign, perhaps a net plus. But public sector unions are a big problem.
